content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: an easy one it can perform well in clash of code test cases are very well, there is no problem in the puzzle as I can see
This look's like a cool Idea. But i don't think that reverse can be done.

I don't think reverse is doable with this one.

Also, I am not sure yet whether I understand what a triplicate number is - especially since in the cases you only give 1 example of an actual triplicate number.
- Is there only a removal possible if there are three identical consecutive digits, or can you also remove from four identical consecutive digits?
- What about 333333333: can you remove all identical consecutive digits (i.e. one removal), or should it always be three at a time?
- Is it only triplicate with three removals, or is 333444 also a triplicate number?
While I ask this questions, I think technically you have it covered in the statement, but it would be nice if a couple more cases with actual triplicate numbers can confirm the varieties of triplicate numbers.

Goal
* Please format "0" and "1" in "0 or 1" as {{constants}}.

* Please state explicitly that {{1}} should be output if [[input]] is a triplicate number and {{0}} otherwise.

* Suggest to change "the number of removals" to "the maximum number of removals that can be performed".

* Pleaes add "." after "decimal digits".

Input
* Please remove the one of the colons.

Output
* Please format "-1" as a {{constant}} (same as in Goal section).

Constraints
* Please remove both constraints as there are cases not following them.

Thanks.
Thank you for your feedback. I've updated the description accordingly.

Thank you for your feedback. :)

It's doable as a reverse clash just tricky to deduce, but that's why there are so many test cases. However, I've added your two examples as test cases as well, so it should be even clearer, I think.

As for the description of the triplicate number, that's why I've bolded "three consecutive identical digits". You cannot remove four digits. I've clarified the description a bit with "exactly" part.

As for your example, 333333333 is indeed a triplicate number, with 3 removals, as you've said "three at a time".

The number of removals does not indicate whether a number is triplicate.
However, the existence of 3 consecutive identical digits may.
Therefore, 333444 and even 334443 are also triplicate numbers, with 2 removals.
Please always write a reason when you approve or reject a contribution. Thanks.

Ok the triplicate number is clear to me now, thanks. Still, I am very hesitant on reverse. The reverse player does not see any case names, and will only see 7 cases. Along those 7 cases, you have 3 different variables that you have to find (triplicate or not, how many removals, invalid or not). That is not a lot of cases per variable in my opinion.

Let's revise the test cases:
122555211 1 3
663633 0 0
9990 0 1
123ASD -1
-1354678 -1
333333333 1 3
333444 1 2

The 2 invalid ones are pretty clear. If it contains letters or is negative it's -1.

The 5 other ones give a hint for the removal count. The players should be able to immediately identify 3 consecutive identical digits and notice that the removal count is greater than 0 in that case. 122555211, 9990 and 333444 will surely steer the player in that direction.

As for the isTriplicate number, I think it's clear that it's either 0 or 1, based on the provided test cases. Plus there are 2 for 0 and 3 for 1. 

I can add another test case, similar to the first one, if you think that would be clearer. I am, however, a bit worried about the number of test cases needed to run.

In my defense, I've seen a couple of brain teasers in reverse mode like this. I like them for the 2 types of wins: figuring out the problem behind and figuring out the code. :D

Let me state the obvious: I'm sharing my opinion here, and it's your clash, so you decide (and hopefully get three approvers :-)). But, in my opinion, it might help if:
- You put all triplicate number cases together
- You add one or two cases with longer triplicate numbers (part of the difficulty is that the second value is very much in the same range as the first. One case with for example 333999111222888777 and another with 446611223332164 will bring the second value a bit higher, so that the distinction between the first and second value becomes more easy to recognize)
- The later cases shift to not triplicate, and finally not valid.

I agree with your two reasons of liking a challenging reverse. However, in relation to the second reason, a defense for including longer triplicate number cases: I'd like my code to also do a 1 5 or even a 1 10 after I proudly have written it.

It's not a clash just for me, that's why I welcome your opinion.

I've done as you've suggested:
- I've grouped the test cases based on their type
- I've sorted the test case groups: triplicates, non-triplicates, invalid
- I've added 2 more cases with your example numbers

Once again, thanks for you feedback! :)

I have to agree with @jddingemanse - the solution is too obscure for a Reverse, I'm afraid.
Excellent for a Classic or Shortest though. Upvote!

I agree that this is a bit obscure. I would encode the isTriplicate variable as a true/false string instead of a number. It will still be too obscure in my opinion, but at least it's a bit clearer what the puzzle solver needs to deduce.
Likewise, invalid numbers should imo have an output of "invalid" or similar.
I like your suggestion. Updated accordingly. Thanks! :)
